attributes.title: Hasbro: A Bargain In The Toy Bin
summary: Shares of Hasbro have gone nearly straight down since the end of November.
Hasbro is highly likely to increase its dividend in the 2nd quarter of 2017.
Shares of Hasbro are undervalued and have a bright future in 2017.

attributes.content:
In this article, I will be detailing why I believe Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) is worth considering for dividend-growth investors. Hasbro had been on a good run since the middle of October, having gone up around $10/share; however, since the stock hit a wall at around the $88 level, shares have nearly given back all their gains.

2017 Outlook

Looking forward, 2017 is set to be a banner year for the box office and thus all the toys that will accompany those movies should make Hasbro a solid performer. If you look at the list of brands of toys that Hasbro sells, it is easy to see why 2017 is setting up to be a banner year for Hasbro. Among the popular brands of toys Hasbro sells based on movies, there are Star Wars, Marvel, Transformers and various Disney movies. The reason why 2017 is setting up to be massive for the toy business is because of the very large and very well-known movie franchises that have movies coming out in 2017. The list includes Guardians of The Galaxy 2, Star Wars Episode 8, Spider-Man Homecoming, Thor: Ragnarok and Transformers: The Last Knight as well as many other movies, those are the biggest.

Revenue Breakdown

If you look at the breakdown of revenues from the 3rd quarter earnings, you will see that Hasbro gets the majority of its revenues from the United States and Canada. However, the company has just over 41% of revenues that come from international sources and thus with the strengthening dollar this could be an issue in 2017, if global sales ramp up because of the globally known movie franchises with movies coming out in 2017.

If as a Hasbro investor or potential investor you are worried about its international exposure, one way to hedge the impact of a strong dollar on its revenues and earnings would be to pair a purchase of Hasbro with a dollar hedge, by purchasing either the PowerShares DB USD Bull ETF (UUP) or the WisdomTree Bloomberg U.S. Dollar Bullish ETF (USDU). If the dollar continues to rise, having a dollar hedge will help soften the blow if Hasbro revenues and earnings were to come in less than expected because of the strong dollar. For those considering Hasbro now, the 4th quarter the last two years has been the quarter where revenues are impacted the most by currency. With the dollar at its highest levels in a decade, it is within reason to assume that the 4th quarter this year will be impacted by the strong dollar.

Dividend Increase

If you look at the dividend history for Hasbro, you can see that the company has historically increased its dividend in the 2nd quarter of each year. As you can see in the table below, Hasbro has a weighted dividend growth rate of 9.44% and I expect the dividend to continue growing over the next 5 years. Specifically, for the likely 2nd quarter dividend increase, I expect that Hasbro will increase its quarterly dividend from $0.51/share to $0.56/share.

To determine if that rate of dividend growth is sustainable over the next five years, I conducted an analysis to see if dividends paid as a percentage of cash flows from operations was less than my self-imposed threshold of 80%. For my calculations, I used the weighted dividend growth rate I calculated of 9.44% and cash flow growth rate of 13.00% from Zacks. The table below shows if Hasbro continues growing its dividend at its current pace that it will continue to be well below my 80% threshold. Based on my estimates, by 2021, Hasbro could be paying an annual dividend of $3.14/share or about $0.785/quarter, which is over 54.02% above the current quarterly dividend.

Valuation Comparison

What also makes Hasbro more appealing is the fact that it is currently trading at a discount to its largest competitor, Mattel (MAT). I ran Mattel through the DCF calculations just as I did for Hasbro above and found that shares of Mattel are overvalued by 4.11%. In addition, when looking at Zacks for projected long-term growth, Hasbro is projected to grow at 13.00% vs. 11.50% for Mattel. Finally, when comparing the P/E ratios of both companies, Hasbro trades at 19.21x and Mattel trades at 27.7x, thus with Hasbro having the superior growth and trading at a significant discount to Mattel, that makes Hasbro a superior choice.

Technical Outlook

The technical outlook for Hasbro is appealing because the stock is right near a key upward trend support level. I believe the stock will bounce off this level and make new highs in the coming year, given all the large movies that are coming out this year. The upward trending red line has been a strong level of support over the last two years and as recently as today, shares of Hasbro sold off in early trading and the low for the day corresponded right to the trend line.

[Image from the ThinkorSwim Platform]

Closing thoughts

In closing, I believe shares of Hasbro are worth considering for dividend-growth investors because the company is highly likely to increase its dividend in the 2nd quarter of 2017 and it has the ability to keep increasing its dividend at a significant pace over the next five years. Given the strong slate of movies coming out in 2017 and the accompanying toys for those movies, as well as shares of Hasbro being undervalued at current levels and an appealing technical outlook, 2017 is setting up to be a big year for Hasbro.
